citation.article-title: Legionella sainthelensi: a new species of Legionella isolated from water near Mt. St. Helens.

p.s: Description of Legionella sainthelensi sp. nov.

Legionella sainthelensi (saint.he' len.si, sainthelensi M. L. mas. gen. n. from Mt. St. Helens is proposed, since the organism was discovered in water in the devastated areas of Mt. St. Helens after the eruption of that volcano)
The type strain of L. sainthelensi is Mt. St.
Helens 4 (ATCC 35248) (it is also the serological reference strain and the DNA hybridization reference strain).
A number of legionellae were isolated throughout the sampling period from water samples taken near Mt. St.
Helens.

The samples which gave the largest number of isolates were obtained from a volcano-produced debris impoundment of a small creek and from the north fork of the Toutle River, which is the main drainage system in the area devastated by volcanic activity.
One of 12 water samples collected on 27 April 1981 yielded isolates of L. pneumophila serogroups 1 and 4.
The new species, L. sainthelensi, was isolated along with strains of L. pneumophila serogroup 1 and L. dumoffii in 1 of 12 samples collected on 4 May.
Two of 14 samples taken in mid-June contained both L. sainthelensi and L. pneumophila serogroup 4.
A Legionella-like organism to be described in the future was found in one of 16 samples collected on 29 June.
One of 10 samples collected in August contained L. pneumophila serogroup 1, L. dumoffii, L. gormanii, L. sainthelensi, and L. longbeachae serogroups 1 and 2.
Five of 11 samples taken at the end of October yielded various legionellae, including strains of L. sainthelensi.
The first strain of L. sainthelensi, which was designated Mt. St.
Helens 3, was isolated from a spring located near Spirit Lake.

Additional strains were subsequently isolated from the north fork of the Toutle River above and below the debris dam and from a cold water impoundment at a 40-foot (ca. 12.2 m) elevation. Legionella species, including L. sainthelensi, were recovered from near the surface to depths of 90 feet (ca. 27.4 m) in lakes and impoundments.
Legionellae were also recovered from swift-flowing water in the Toutle River.
The pH of these waters varied from 7.2 to 8.4, and the temperature profiles in the areas where recorded varied from 17°C in April to 10°C in September.

Other microbial flora collected from these cold-water sites included species of Nodularia, Pseudonabaena, Anabaena, Oscillatoria, Nitzschia, Tribonema, Chlamydomonas, Chlorella, and microflagellates (21).

At the time that legionellae were recovered, dissolved organic carbon concentrations had decreased, metal concentrations remained higher than normal, and phytoplanktonic photosynthesis was insignificant.
The predominant algal flora were unicellular green algae and filamentous Tribonema and Anabaena species.
The total number of algae was between 6 x 104 and 7 x 102/liter.
Ciliated protozoa were found at concentrations of 102 to 105 liter (21).
Colonies of L. sainthelensi appeared on all three Legionella enrichment media on day 3 of incubation and increased in size for several days.
No growth occurred on blood agar.
The colonies were gray with a smooth, but slightly textured, surface (ground glass appearance).
Colonies were raised with an entire edge.
The six isolates of L. sainthelensi (Mt. St.
Helens 3, 4, 7, 8, 10, and 11) had identical biochemical characteristics.
They were thin, gram-negative, nonsporeforming, non-acid fast, motile rods. L. sainthelensi strains were positive in reactions for catalase, oxidase, gelatin liquefaction, and beta-lactamase.
They were negative in tests for urease, hydrolysis of hippurate, fermentation of DAPPL glucose, and reduction of nitrates.
Colonies of L. sainthelensi did not show blue-white autofluorescence under a Woods lamp.
These reactions are similar to those of other legionellae.
Biochemically, L. sainthelensi can be separated from the autofluorescent species L. bozemanii, L. dumoffii, and L. gormanii because it does not autofluoresce.
It is separable from L. pneumophila by its negative hippurate test, from L. micdadei by its production of beta-lactamase, and from L. oakridgensis by its motility.
It is biochemically indistinguishable from L. jordanis, L. longbeachae, and L. wadsworthii.
The cellular fatty acid composition of six isolates of L. sainthelensi is presented in Table 1.
Each isolate was grown and tested at least three times, and the values are means from these determinations.

The fatty acids of these six isolates are qualitatively similar to those of other Legionella species with the characteristic features of the presence of isobranched-chain 14- and 16-carbon acids (i-14:0, i-16:0) and anteisobranched-chain 15- and 17-carbon acids (a-15:0, a-17:0) together with relatively large amounts of a monounsaturated straight-chain 16-carbon acid (16:1) and the absence of individual hydroxy acids at concentrations greater than 1% (6, 16-18).
Like other legionellae, L. sainthelensi contains relatively large amounts (50 to 62%) of the total acids as branched-chain acids (4, 6, 16-18).

Quantitatively, the fatty acid composition of L. sainthelensi is most similar to those of L. bozemanii (4, 14, 18), L. longbeachae (16), L. dumoffii (4, 18), L. jordanis (4, 18), L. gormanii (4, 18), and L. wadsworthii (6) but is distinct from those of L. pneumophila (4, 17, 18), L. oakridgensis (18), and L. micdadei (4, 9, 18).
Each of the six isolates of L. sainthelensi, Mt. St.
Helens 3, 4, 7, 8, 10, and 11, contained approximately equal amounts of ubiquinones Q9, Q10, Q1l, and Q12; no menaquinones were detected in any strain.

This ubiquinone pattern is similar to those of L. bozemanii, L. dumoffii, and L. longbeachae but is distinct from those of L. pneumophila, L. micdadei, L. jordanis, L. wadsworthii, L. oakridgensis, and L. feeleii (10; unpublished data).
The patterns were very reproducible, since essentially identical results were obtained with each of the isolates grown and processed three separate times.

The presence of Q1l and Q12 as major components in L. sainthelensi is consistent with our previous data which show that all Legionella contain ubiquinones with more than 10 isoprene units in the side chain (10).

Thus, analysis for ubiquinones and cellular fatty acids provide chemical data for clear definition of Legionella; in some instances the quantitative data from these analyses are useful for definition of groups or species within the genus (10, 14).
On the bases of biochemical reactions, fatty acid analysis, and ubiquinone content, one still cannot separate L. sainthelensi from L. longbeachae.

All L. sainthelensi isolates were tested with diagnostic dilutions of fluorescein conjugates made to the reference strains of L. pneumophila serogroups 1 to 8, L. micdadei, L. bozemanii, L. dumoffli, L. gormanii, L. longbeachae serogroups 1 and 2, L. jordanis, L. oakridgensis, and L. wadsworthii.
Cells of all six Mt. St.
Helens strains stained dimly (2+) with conjugates for L. longbeachae serogroup 2 (Tucker 1) and L. oakridgensis (Oak Ridge 10) and gave no reaction with all other conjugates.
As a further stringent test of serological relatedness, the isolates were tested with 1:8 dilutions (10 mg of immunoglobulin G per ml, considered undilute) of conjugates made to the above organisms.
At.this dilution, cells of the Mt. St.
Helens isolates stained brightly with conjugates to L. longbeachae serogroup 1 (Long Beach 4), L. longbeachae serogroup 2, and L. oakridgensis.
When these three organisms were similarly tested with conjugates prepared to Mt. St.
Helens 3, 4, and 7, L. oakridgensis and L. longbeachae serogroup 1 cells stained 3 to 4+ and L. longbeachae serogroup 2 cells stained to a lesser extent (2+) with the three conjugates.
At the diagnostic working dilution, these conjugates stained the cells of L. oakridgensis and L. longbeachae serogroup 1, but not L. longbeachae serogroup 2, dimly (2+).
The staining patterns of all Mt. St.
Helens isolates were identical with all heterologous and homologous conjugates tested.
Conjugates for Mt. St.
Helens 3, 4, and 7, which were cross-absorbed with cells of the heterologous Mt. St.
Helens strains, were not reactive with either the homologous or heterologous Mt. St.
Helens antigens (including Mt. St.
Helens 8, 10, and 11).
Absorption of L. longbeachae serogroups 1 and 2 and L. oakridgensis conjugates with Mt. St.
Helens 4 cells removed all reactivity for cells of all Mt. St.
Helens isolates (Table 2).
The cross-reactions between L. longbeachae serogroups 1 and 2 were also eliminated or greatly reduced after this absorption.
When the Mt. St.

Helens 4 conjugate was absorbed with cells of L. longbeachae serogroup 1, reactions of this conjugate with both L. longbeachae serogroups 1 and 2 were removed, but reactivity with L. oakridgensis remained intact.
Subsequent absorption of the conjugate with cells of L. oakridgensis eliminated this cross-reaction.
Based on direct fluorescent antibody testing, L. sainthelensi is antigenically related to L. oakridgensis and to both serogroups of L. longbeachae.
The reciprocal cross-reactions of L. sainthelensi with the two serogroups of L. longbeachae appear to be due to the same antigen, since absorption of the conjugates to Mt. St.
Helens 4 with cells of L. longbeachae serogroup 1 removes reactivity of the conjugate for both L. longbeachae serogroups 1 and 2.
Another distinct antigenic locus is evidently involved in the reciprocal cross-reaction with L. oakridgensis.
The heterologous cross-reactions observed are not of significant intensity to cause confusion when conjugates are used at their diagnostic dilutions.
However, because of possible antigenic variation and differences in reagent specificity, it is desirable to absorb conjugates with cells of the heterologous organism to achieve complete specificity.

At this point in the investigation L. sainthelensi could have represented a new serogroup in L. longbeachae, a new serogroup in another Legionella species that differed slightly in its biochemical characteristics, or a new species.
DNA hybridization was necessary to choose between these alternatives.
L. sainthelensi strain Mt. St.
Helens 4 DNA was labeled in vitro with 32Pi and tested for relatedness to DNAs from other L. sainthelensi strains and DNAs from the type strains of all described Legionella species (Table 3).
Two other L. sainthelensi strains were more than 90% related to Mt. St.
Helens 4 in reactions done at both 60°C (optimal for DNA reassociation) and 75°C (a stringent reassociation criterion where only closely related sequences can form stable DNA heteroduplexes).
The thermal stability of the related DNA sequences indicated that there were 0.5% unpaired nucleotide bases (divergence).
Thus, these strains all belonged to the same species.

Since all six strains of L. sainthelensi were identical biochemically, in analyses of cellular fatty acids and quinones, and in their 0 antigens, it was therefore considered sufficient to test only three of the six strains for DNA relatedness. L. sainthelensi was 36% related to the type strain of L. longbeachae, with evidence of 8.5% divergence in the related sequences.
Interestingly, these two species showed antigenic cross-reactions.
Relatedness of L. sainthelensi to the other described Legionella species was 3 to 14%.

On the basis of genetic relatedness, strains of L. sainthelensi are a single species that showed a significant amount of relatedness to L. longbeachae and some degree of relatedness to all other legionellae. L. sainthelensi thus belongs in the genus Legionella because of its cultural characteristics, biochemical and serological characteristics, branched-chain fatty acid composition, ubiquinone content, and DNA relatedness.
